bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William D. Wrightson, October 22, 1918

div1.p: Carter praises the Virginia mosquito control work of Bailey.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to William D. Wrightson, October 22, 1918
div1.opener:
Mr. Bailey
/LC
OFFICE OF
MEDICAL OFFICER IN CHARGE
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
BALTIMORE, MD.
October 22, 1918.
Colonel William Wrightson,
Sanitary Corps, U. S. A.,
Surgeon General's Office,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Colonel Wrightson:
div1.p:
Mr. Bailey of the Navy asks me to write you about his mos-
quito work with my people at Norfolk and Portsmouth. He and
two others were the Mosquito Inspectors, whose duties were main-
ly with parts of the area breeding and producing Anopheles. I
saw a good deal of his work and considered it good, as did Van
Havenberg, who had charge of the District. He was always inter-
ested in his work--enthusiastic, steady and reliable. He is, I
believe, a good entomologist and something more--a man with prac-
tical knowledge of the breeding habits of Anopheles mosquitoes.

Of his engineering attainments I cannot speak, nor of his
ability in handling men. He has, however, seen considerable of
Van Hovenberg's work the past summer and--save LePrince--we have
no better man. On account too of the rather unusual problems in
his District--tides and salt water--the control of mosquito pro-
duction there involved a number of methods more than one usually
finds and one with his intelligence and education cannot but
have profitted by his association with Van Hovenberg.
div1.closer: Very sincerely your friend, Assistant Surgeon General.
